Award.AwardTitle: International Collaboration in Chemistry: Synthetic Organic Approaches to Carbon Nanotubes with Well-Defined Structure
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this International Collaboration in Chemistry between US Investigators and their Counterparts Abroad (ICC) project funded by the Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry Program of the Chemistry Division, Yves Rubin of the University of California at Los Angeles will develop methods for the solution-phase self-assembly of carbon-rich macrocycles into columnar stacks and study the controlled polymerization of these stacks into nanotubular carbon-rich systems in solution and on surfaces by STM. This work includes an international collaboration with Prof. Yoshito Tobe of Osaka University, Japan. Prof. Tobe's work will be funded by the Japan Society for the Promotion of Science (JSPS). The ultimate thrust of this project is to achieve carbonization of these nanotubular carbon-rich products into well-defined carbon nanotubes with precise location of side-chains. The research has three complementary components. In the first part, the research will focus on the use of molecular assembly of self-complementary carbon-rich macrocyclic derivatives to achieve the correct stacking parameters that lead to facile thermal topochemical polymerization of columnar stacks of macrocycles. In the second part, controlled polymerization of the carbon-rich macrocycles will be examined and optimized, both within single crystals through heat, irradiation or high pressure, or with self-assembled nanotubules on a surface by pulsed voltage from STM tips, UV irradiation, or heat. Finally, a study of the structures and properties of the resulting carbon nanotubes will determine if they have the desired well-defined widths as well as carbon network and substituent topologies corresponding to their designed molecular precursors. The broader impacts involve training graduate and undergraduate students, enhancing research infrastructure by bringing together an international collaborative group, and the potential societal benefits of a long sought access to well-defined carbon nanotubes with unique electronic properties.

The availability of carbon nanotubes, ultrasmall tubes comprised of a single layer of carbon atoms, with defined width has been a grand challenge of carbon-based nanotechnology. Ready access to carbon nanotubes with precise dimensions and electronic properties is not yet possible, and this research seeks to solve part of this problem by achieving a controlled formation of large sections of carbon nanotubes. The results of this research could ultimately impact industries and commercial products that would utilize nanoelectronics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Graphene and carbon nanotubes (CNTs) possess extraordinary electrical, thermal, and mechanical properties that exceed those of any other known materials. Their discovery has ignited a huge research effort in fundamental materials science and engineering, which has resulted in substantial advances in nanoelectronics, photovoltaics, energy storage devices, chemical and biological sensors, artificial skin materials, and electronic devices that can withstand mechanical deformations such as bending, stretching or folding. Graphene, in particular, is considered a possible replacement for silicon in nanoelectronics owing to its exceptional carrier mobility (>200,000 cm2 V-1 s-1). However, the lack of a bandgap in semi-metallic graphene has prevented its application to logic devices such as field-effect transistors (FETs), which are the essential devices behind almost all modern electronics and optoelectronics. Fortunately, a substantial bandgap can be obtained in relatively narrow ribbons of graphene (width < 10 nm) through the lateral confinement of charge carriers. These compounds have been termed graphene nanoribbons (GNRs). Theoretical calculations have predicted two factors that are crucial for GNRs to achieve a bandgap similar to that of silicon (~1.1 eV), the latter being the benchmark semiconductor used in most modern electronics: (1) the GNR needs to have armchair edges to be semiconducting; zigzag edges lead to metallic ribbons (Fig. 1). (2) The GNR width needs to be < 2 nm (11 carbon width) to induce a bandgap higher than 1 eV that will be suitable for practical semiconductor applications. During the duration of this grant, we built a large body of work by taking a two-pronged approach to the formation of carbon nanotubes and graphene nanoribbons: 1) First, we explored ways to synthesize carbon nanotubes with defined topology and width from well-defined synthetic precursors by the self-assembly of dehydroannulene macrocycles into tubular networks to form well-ordered crystals, followed by their topochemical polymerization and graphitization at higher temperatures (Fig. 2). 2) We used a simplified approach for this project by studying the topochemical polymerization of butadiyne derivatives, which form polydiacetylene precursors of graphene nanoribbons. We demonstrated that these can be converted into graphene nanoribbons under surprisingly mild heating (<200 ?C).  Fig. 2. Conceptual representation of the crystallization of dehydroannulene macrocycles into tubular networks to form well-ordered crystals, followed by their topochemical polymerization and graphitization at higher temperatures.Overall, our investigation into the topochemical polymerization of either linear or cyclic butadiyne derivatives was highly fruitful. In particular, we were able to show that graphene nanoribbons can be formed under surprisingly mild conditions. We plan to continue this work to study the mechanisms of these transformations on smaller molecules (model compounds), rather that difficult to analyze polymers. We will also extend this work to other precursors that can be transformed into carbon-rich materials.


Last Modified: 01/19/2016
Modified by: Yves F Rubin

Their discovery has ignited a huge research effort in fundamental materials science and engineering, which has resulted in substantial advances in nanoelectronics, photovoltaics, energy storage devices, chemical and biological sensors, artificial skin materials, and electronic devices that can withstand mechanical deformations such as bending, stretching or folding. Graphene, in particular, is considered a possible replacement for silicon in nanoelectronics owing to its exceptional carrier mobility (>200,000 cm2 V-1 s-1). However, the lack of a bandgap in semi-metallic graphene has prevented its application to logic devices such as field-effect transistors (FETs), which are the essential devices behind almost all modern electronics and optoelectronics. Fortunately, a substantial bandgap can be obtained in relatively narrow ribbons of graphene (width < 10 nm) through the lateral confinement of charge carriers. These compounds have been termed graphene nanoribbons (GNRs). Theoretical calculations have predicted two factors that are crucial for GNRs to achieve a bandgap similar to that of silicon (~1.1 eV), the latter being the benchmark semiconductor used in most modern electronics: (1) the GNR needs to have armchair edges to be semiconducting; zigzag edges lead to metallic ribbons (Fig. 1). (2) The GNR width needs to be < 2 nm (11 carbon width) to induce a bandgap higher than 1 eV that will be suitable for practical semiconductor applications. In particular, we were able to show that graphene nanoribbons can be formed under surprisingly mild conditions. We will also extend this work to other precursors that can be transformed into carbon-rich materials. Last Modified: 01/19/2016 Submitted by: Yves F Rubin
